newsitem.title: CHINA: China betting $200 million on new casino resort.
newsitem.headline: China betting $200 million on new casino resort.

text.p: China is betting that a planned $200 million casino and seaside resort will propel the communist nation into the ranks of free-wheeling gambling spots such as Macau, officials said on Monday.
The luxury entertainment complex is to be built on a peninsula near the northern port city of Tianjin, said Waysun Liao, general manager of Tianjin Xiang Dao Resort and Casino Co Ltd.

Construction of the casino, to cost $20-$30 million, would start on September 20 and was expected to begin trial operations in March 1997. The resort would also include a hotel, a stage for shows and a water sports centre, Liao said by telephone.
Beijing hopes to draw foreign tourists and businessmen living in China who in the past have travelled abroad for such entertainment, he said.
"They won't have to commute, go to Hong Kong, Macau or other places," Liao said.

Although China's ruling Communist Party has maintained a strict ban on gambling, rapid economic growth had created huge demand for casinos and luxury pleasure centres, and prompted the government to back this first gambling venture, he said.
"We have all kinds of hotels but we don't have resorts, international, five star-type resorts," he said of China's tourist industry.
"The issue is not whether you like it (a gambling resort) or not, but it's a necessity that they must accommodate such kind of service," he said.

The government had set up Tianjin Xiang Dao to build and oversee the resort, while funding and management of the facility was being handled by Farside International, a subsidiary of Hong Kong's Gala Corp, he said.
Farside was talking to casino firms from Hong Kong, Macau and Australia to handle management of the gambling operation but had not yet reached a final decision, he said.
